title: Deputy founder will be chief to most as tech floods Young Rich List
text:
Reflecting investor hunger for established revenue streams and high growth potential at a time when cash rates are near zero, a basket of eight listed SaaS companies assembled by the Financial Review – Atlassian, Dropbox, HubSpot, Salesforce, Shopify, WiseTech, Xero and Zoom – are currently trading at an average enterprise value to revenue ratio of 18.7 times.

Atlassian itself is at nearly 28 times, helping push the stakes of its Young Rich Lister founders Scott Farquhar and Mike Cannon-Brookes beyond $12 billion apiece.

The SaaS boom is also set to keep long-time Young Rich Listers Mitchell Harper and Ben Richardson high up the 2019 edition, thanks to their stakes in BigCommerce and Campaign Monitor respectively, even if neither are no longer involved day-to-day in the businesses they founded.

Meanwhile a basket of 13 listed online marketplace businesses, from Amazon to Yelp, Carsales to Seek, boast an average enterprise value to earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation ratio of 28.47 times.

This universe excludes loss-makers like Zillow, and outliers like Australia's Freelancer.com, which sits today at 2736 times. It must also be noted that the final Young Rich List will value private companies considering as many meaningful metrics as possible - single valuation metrics were chosen for the SaaS and marketplace universes for indicative purposes in this research only.

Such elevated multiples do help explain why venture capitalists have recently put a price tag of $6.3 billion on expatriate Ori Allon's luxury property marketplace, Compass, and a $3.6 billion valuation on Canva, which straddles the SaaS sector with its corporate subscription product and marketplaces with its ever-expanding image library.

Deputy's $308.60-per-share Series B was the sign of a genuine "unicorn contender", according to Amanda Hjorring, chief operating officer of Melbourne's Square Peg Capital, which backed the round alongside California's Institutional Venture Partners and the returning OpenView.

Advertisement

"With Deputy you've got amazing founders and a rostering system that's now in 90,000 workplaces and 80 countries, yet they feel they've only just touched the surface," Ms Hjorring told last week's Morgan Stanley Australia Summit in Sydney.

"The beauty of it is that it's a product-led sales business. It's viral among shift workers because it means they can easily communicate with each other and change rostering, and when they move jobs they take it with them, or at least show the new employer."

Deputy could already be worth far more than the nominal $423 million indicated by last November's Series B.

It doubled revenue to $15.2 million in 2017-18 from $7.5 million the year before, according to accounts recently lodged with the corporate regulator.

The company did not provide a current revenue run rate for this article, but a doubling again to $30 million in 2018-19 would see Deputy valued at $561 million, applying the current trading of the Financial Review's SaaS universe.

The high marketplace multiples might have already made a unicorn out of Envato, founded in 2006 by Melburnian couple Collis and Cyan Ta'eed.

Its EBITDA fell to $26 million in 2017-18 because of a large employee expense as it pivoted to its subscription-based Elements product. However, if the prior year's $36 million EBITDA could be considered a normalised result, the 28.47 times enterprise value to EBITDA ratio fetched by its marketplace peers would qualify it for a 10-digit valuation.
description: 38-year-old Ashik Ahmed is set to debut in the top 20 of a Young Rich List that is on track to be richer than ever.
